advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Basic, It is magic"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SILEX DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advertising for the MZ 1500 (with the Quick Disk drive) in a Japanese magazine.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #4 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Best''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://uratomo.hp.infoseek.co.jp/game/museum/msx/f1xd.htm" target="_blank">Dreaming Tomorrow</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTWARE CATALOGUE</strong></font><br><blockquote>AcornSoft software catalogue for the Electron</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 1-2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The same women has changed its shirt... But hey, what's the message behind this pictures ? Would it be that it's sexy to work on an Alpha Plus, or that women prefer men owning an Alpha Plus ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIAGRAMS</strong></font><br><blockquote>PMI-80 diagram located in the case cover.<br> If you are interested in more diagrams of the PMI-80, dowload this zipped <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Tesla_PMI80_Diagrams.zip">file</a> holding three diagrams of the whole system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #6 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The new sale price is $99.95 instead of 149.95 <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The ZX81 represents the latest technology in microelectronics. More than 10,000 are sold every week. In fact, the ZX81 is the best selling personal computer in the world.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> As the American magazine 'Byte' commented, "for some time to come the 1040STF will be the clear leader in price/performance." </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR NETWORK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar is the network version of the SuperBrain. Each SuperBrain computer became an 'intelligent' video terminal called a Video Processing Unit and containing its own microprocessor and 64 KB of RAM. Single or double floppy disc could be added for 350 KB to 1.5 MB local storage. Up to 255 terminals could be connected into the same network. Maximum cable length between two terminal was one mile at a 1.6 MB data transfer rate. Each of them could share a disk storage system, from 10 to 96 MB with CP/M operating system. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
This Word Processor was originally produced by Syntrex Inc. Eatontown, New Jersey and sold under the brand of Olivetti. This was in 1980 (Version 1 of Syntrex Operating System was not sold); in 1981 the completely redesigned Version was sold with the system worldwide.
The picture shows the base unit of the ETS 1010 (Electronic Typing System) It came with a display unit and one could attach an electronic typewriter (usually an ET121 or ET221) or a keyboard.
The cabinet socket plugged into a central storage device which could support 8 or 16 ETS units at a time plus 2 printers. There was a 10 MB hard drive option (later 20 MB Winchester HDD) which was the size of a chest freezer.
A variety of daisy wheel printers could be used with the system: PR430 / DY310 / DY450 / ET121 / ET221
There also existed an ETS2010 which was an updated version. It used an 80186 CPU, had more memory and was compabitable with all data on ETS1010.
________
Contributor: Robert Scrivener, Dr. Joachim Mueller, Charles Moss
computer.name: ETS 1010
computer.peripherals: 10 or 20 MB hard disk, daisy wheel printer
computer.ports: Communication port, Cabinet socket, Keyboard socket, Monitor socket, Power input
